I'm not sure to understand why would a south korean player join the chinese league? Aren't they underpayed there?
I google it and heres what i found in their currency 1 Yuan( Chinese currency) = 163.98 Won (south Korean Currency). Think the Chinese currency worth more.

effectively, I'm not talking about the value of the currency. otherwise european players would be the richest...

During the world cup S3, Tabe said he was earning something about 600~800 euros a month when he was still playing for Royal club, and decided he'd resign from his lol career cause the wage was way too low.
The question is, do Korean players also earn that ridiculous salary? if not, I don't get why they'd transfer to China

the highest paid pros in China makes way more than those in Korea. I think DK.Burning makes about 50k in USD a year only from salary (and this number was 3-4 years old, it must be more now), then you add all the tourney money and other bonuses. Tabe wasn't making a lot because he never won an international title, WE's weixiao and EDG's clearlove and fzzf are prob the highest paid along all.

800 euros is about 5k yuan(chinese currency) in china, and he thinks he earns not much? he isnt a football player.and you cant just convert it stright away from euros to yuan by the exchange rate. like

you do realize this does not answer his question? the currency is the nominal exchange rate. this doesn't tell the value of the real wages that they are being paid in china, neither the relative value of real wages between south Korea and China.
To simplify the answer you would have to multiply the nominal wage with the exchange rate (163,98). this would be a simple answer, but it isn't fully sufficient.
This i because it doesn't calculate the relative level of inflation between the two countries. i believe (though not sure) that you could estimate this by multiplying it all with (price-level-china/price-level-Skorea). this would give some insight into the strength of the wage in china compared to Korea. but yet again we don't know the wages they pay in china nor Korea, which leaves us unable to answer Tsuyoku's question; "aren't they underpaid in China".
The wages are usually strictly confidential, so i believe the question is impossible to answere.

if u really wanna try; you can try combining the gini-index of South korea, and China; with the GDP pr. Capita. in chained values (cleansed from inflation; might be called sticky prices also). this might give some insight, though neither a viable nor direct answer.
I tried looking for the gini index of both China and south korea and only found numbers from 2005 and 1998 respectively, which is kind of useless. It might be possible to find though.

sorry if my english isn't sufficient enough for you; or grammatically correct: Im not a native, and would neither expect a native to write perfectly in their own language.

"LPL teams will be restricted to only two foreign players going forward to prevent a dilution of the Chinese talent pool. " WOW! That's exactly something I brought up as regards leagues like the English Premier League in soccer and MOST such sports leagues. The number of foreign players are limited per each team. And yet LMQ is entirely foreign nationals playing in NA? But a team comprised only of NA/EU players could NEVER compete in the LPL under these rules. Isn't that amazing HYPOCRISY! Why isn't NA protected from similar "DILUTION" of talent?

because the rule is kinda weird. bringing in foreign talent will only improve the strength of the players in NALCS, because they are able to learn from each other. even if this would empty out the entire NALCS of NA players, it would still improve the skill level of the NA players. Simply because this would just increase solo queue and team queue level, and thereby increase the relative skills of the challenger players. Naturally NA would in turn reclaim their spots in the NALCS as new and stronger challenger teams are formed. After all in NA there is more North American talent than Chinese, European and Korean talent.
If u want NA or any other region to be able to rival the Korean, you should be happy every time new foreign talent joins any league. It helps improve play styles and make "dominant strategies".

I like how people are acting as if the NA and EU LCS will suddenly be flooded by Chinese and Koreans if we don't impose restrictions. There are already a lot of outside factors that would prevent players from coming to these scenes. The first is that they aren't guaranteed a spot unless they invest in the challenger scene. The Korean iteration of Quantic gaming proved that you can't ship a bunch of strong players to the US and have them automatically qualify for the LCS. Quantic tried to rush their entry, so they got destroyed on the first day. LMQ had to invest a lot of time in the US. They had to climb the NA challenger scene and take part in the challenger series, a process that takes a least a split and a half. That's a lot of time to be living in a foreign country with no guarantee that you'll make it pro (granted, LMQ had the closest we can call a guaranteed spot based on their performance).

Long story short, ask yourself if you would want to be living in a foreign country for at least half a year with no guarantee that you'll end up making it pro.
Say all you want, but I thoroughly enjoyed that LMQ/C9 game :)
